gen:ReportedAttribute.com:Text: Goal 1. Eradicate poverty in all its forms and everywhere

1.3 Put in place social protection systems and measures for all, adapted to the national context, including social protection floors, and ensure that, by 2030, a significant proportion of the poor and vulnerable people benefit from them
1.3.1. Number of mutual associations engaged in the promotion of community development programs (%)
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
Number of the population covered by a mutualist association compared to the total number of the population
N / A
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling the data for the calculation of this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the demographic and health situation of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.
Number of the population covered by a mutualist association compared to the total number of the population
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at the national level, province, area of residence (Woman aged 15 to 49: Urban area; Rural area - Man aged 15 to 49: Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017

Goal 1. Eradicate poverty in all its forms and everywhere

1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, especially the poor and vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources and have access to basic services, land ownership, control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources and new technologies and financial services tailored to their needs, including microfinance
1.4.1. Percentage of the population living below the poverty line
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
Number of the population below the national poverty line in relation to the total population
ECVMB
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the situation on the living conditions of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey that is very resource-intensive and almost all of the funding comes from partners.
Number of the population below the national poverty line compared to the total population
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on Household Living Conditions in Burundi

Goal 1. Eradicate poverty in all its forms and everywhere

1.a Ensure a significant mobilization of resources from multiple sources, including through the strengthening of cooperation for development, in order to endow developing countries, in particular the least developed countries, with adequate and predictable means implement programs and policies aimed at ending poverty in all its forms
1.a.1.Proportion of resources directly allocated by the State to poverty reduction programs
MFBCD
IRAMBONA Eric
eric.irambona85@gmail.com
This is the share of the state budget allocated to poverty reduction programs
Ministry of Finance, Budget and Development Cooperation
Data is collected from administrative documents
Collection is done annually
Every year
MFBCD
MFBCD
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the distribution of the state budget.
The update of the indicator requires an exhaustive collection of all government expenditure
Budget allocated to poverty reduction programs from the State budget multiplied by 100
The data is validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level.
Data can be compared to past data
Budget Usage Report

ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
It is defined as a height-for-age (TAZ) z-score less than two standard deviations of the median of the reference population.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 0-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi

Goal 2. End hunger, achieve food security, improve nutrition and promote sustainable agriculture

2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving by 2025 internationally agreed targets for stunting and wasting in children under 5 years, and meet the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant or breastfeeding women and the elderly
2.2.1. Number of underweight children under 5 (Acute malnutrition)
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

Acute malnutrition is a form of undernutrition. It is caused by a decrease in food intake and / or associated disease causing bilateral edema and / or sudden weight loss. Its severe form is characterized by the presence of bilateral edema or emaciation (low weight-for-height z-score or low MUAC). We distinguish the Global Acute Malnutrition (MAG) which is the sum of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) and Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM).
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020

The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 years old.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
It is defined as a weight-for-height (PTZ) z-score less than two standard deviations of the median of the reference population.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 6-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the nutritional situation in Burundi

ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

These are the deaths of women recorded during pregnancy, childbirth or after childbirth, whether in health structures or in the community. Number of women per hundred thousand live births

The indicator measures the deaths of women during pregnancy, childbirth or after childbirth, both in health facilities and in the community. The denominator is estimated from data from the population projection.

The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level

Proportion of children who are underweight for their age.
Nutritional surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reports on the nutritional situation of children under 5 and the food security of the population.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources and most of which is donated by partners
Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are underweight for their age in relation to the total number of children under 5 years old.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, Place of residence (Total; Girls; Boys; 0-11 months; 12-23 months; 24-59 months)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Survey on the Nutritional Situation and Food Security in Burundi

NIYUNGEKO Jacqueline

Health statistics yearbook
Data is collected from administrative registers of health facilities
Collection is done annually
Every year
MSPLS
MSPLS
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the health situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires exhaustive collection in health facilities. For most of the data, data from private health facilities are not taken into account.
Ratio of the population aged 15 to 49 tested positive for HIV / AIDS to the total population aged 15 to 49 multiplied by 100
The results of the data collection are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level and by sex. (Total; Women; Men)

MEFTP

Bureau of Educational Planning and Statistics, Statistical Yearbook
Data are collected from surveys of schools using the Questionnaire
Collection is done annually
Every year
MEFTP
MEFTP
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the educational situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires a survey of schools in the territory of Burundi. The reluctance is noted for private establishments.
Number of girls / Number of boys
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level

Goal 4. Ensure equitable, inclusive and quality education and lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.a Build or adapt existing schools that are child, disabled and gender-friendly and provide a safe, non-violent, inclusive and effective learning environment for all

4.a.1.Proportion of schools with access to: a) electricity; b) the Internet for educational purposes; c) computers for educational purposes; d) infrastructure and materials adapted to disabled pupils; e) a basic supply of potable water;
MEFTP
BARANKIGA Eugenie
eugenibar2017@gmail.com
It is the ratio between the number of establishments with a given infrastructure and the total number of establishments.
Bureau of Educational Planning and Statistics, Statistical Yearbook
Data are collected from surveys of schools using the Questionnaire
Collection is done annually
Every year
MEFTP
MEFTP
The Ministerial departments are the members of the SSN whose mission is to collect, process and disseminate the data of their sector.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the educational situation in Burundi.
Updating the indicator requires a survey of schools in the territory of Burundi. The reluctance is noted for private establishments.
Number of establishments with a given infrastructure divided by the total number of establishments, multiplied by 100
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: internal validation and validation at the CTIS level before publication

The indicator is available at national level and by cycle. ([Drinking water: Preschool, Basic, General and educational post-basic, Technical post-basic]; [Electricity: Preschool, Basic, General and educational post-basic, Technical post-basic])
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level

Objective 6. Guarantee access for all to sustainably managed water supply and sanitation services
6.1 By 2030, ensure universal and equitable access to drinking water at an affordable cost
6.1.1. Drinking water coverage rate (%): Urban environment Rural environment
Burundi Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies (ISTEEBU)
NDAYISENGA Modest
Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring Service "SESSSP"
Head of the Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring department
1156 BUJUMBURA
ndayimode2010@gmail.com

This is the percentage between the number of households (or of the population) obtaining water from facilities deemed capable of supplying drinking water (connections to the running water distribution network, standpipes, boreholes equipped with pump, gravity water supply or rural pumping) and the total number of households (or the total population) at the national level.
Percentage
ISTEEBU, Survey on the living conditions of Burundian households (ECVMB) 2013-2014
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the level of coverage of the population with drinking water, an essential element for social well-being, in this case good health.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive. The indicator cannot be calculated by gender.

Ratio between the number of households (or the population) obtaining water from facilities deemed capable of supplying drinking water (connections to the running water distribution network, standpipes, boreholes fitted with motorized pumps human, gravity water supply or pumping in rural areas) and the total number of households (or the total population) at the national level, expressed as a percentage at the national level
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Household Survey Report, archives of the Ministry of Water, Energy and Mines (REGIDESO and AHAMR)
Objective 6. Guarantee access for all to sustainably managed water supply and sanitation services

6.2 By 2030, ensure access for all, under equitable conditions, to adequate sanitation and hygiene services and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and people in vulnerable situations
6.2.1. % of the population with access to adequate sanitation
Burundi Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies (ISTEEBU) / REGIDESO
NDAYISENGA Modest / WAKANA Ferdinand
Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring Service "SESSSP" / MHEM statistics and planning service
Head of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring service / SDG focal point at MHEM
1156 BUJUMBURA
ndayimode2010@gmail.com / wakanafer@yahoo.fr

This is the percentage of the population with access to improved sanitation facilities. These improved facilities include flush toilets with septic tanks, traditional improved or ventilated latrines, and sewage-connected latrines. The excreta treatment system is considered adequate if it is private (not shared) and if it prevents human contact with human excrement
Percentage
Household surveys
Data are collected from household surveys using the household questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2020
ISTEEBU / Ministry of Hydraulics, Energy and Mines
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it reflects the level of coverage of the population in terms of sanitation, an essential element for social well-being, in this case good health.
Updating the indicator most often requires a household survey which requires a lot of resources. The indicator cannot be calculated by gender.
Ratio of ordinary households connected to a sump, ditch, main collector and soak-off well and all ordinary households, expressed as a percentage

The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication. Administrative data are validated by the technical committee for statistical information (CTIS)
The indicator is available at national level, province, area of residence (Total; Urban area; Rural area)
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Annual report of the Ministry of Water, Energy and Mines.

MFBCDE
Eric IRAMBONA

Official development assistance (ODA) is defined as the flows of public finance administered with the promotion of economic development and the well-being of developing countries as the main objective, and which are concessional in nature with a subsidy element of at least 25% (using a fixed 10 percent discount rate). By convention, ODA flows include contributions from donor government agencies, at all levels, to developing countries (bilateral ODA) and multilateral institutions.

[(Real GDP n-real GDP n-1) / real GDP n-1] * 100

Total compensation of employees in relation to gross domestic product, expressed as a percentage

This indicator is relevant because it highlights the difference between the crude birth rate and the crude death rate. It measures the increase of a population over a period of time due only to births and deaths

Goal 5. Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls
5.2 Eliminate from public and private life all forms of violence against women and girls, including trafficking and sexual exploitation and other types of exploitation
5.2.1 Proportion of women and girls aged 15 and over who have lived as a couple victims of physical or sexual violence during the previous 12 months
ISTEEBU
NDAYISENGA Modest
Department of Social Studies and Statistics and Poverty Monitoring, Ponit focal ODD
Head of Service and Focal Point
ndayimode2010@gmail.com
It is the ratio between women and girls aged 15 and over who have lived as a couple victims of physical or sexual violence during the previous 12 months and all women and girls aged 15 and over.
Data are collected from household surveys using the "household" questionnaire
The probable date of the next collection will be 2021 (Next DHS)
ISTEEBU
ISTEEBU is responsible for compiling this indicator at the national level
ISTEEBU is the body recognized by the Burundian government for the collection, processing and dissemination of official statistics helping in planning and decision-making.
The indicator is relevant because it captures the situation of violence against women.
Updating the indicator requires a household survey which is very resource intensive.

Women and girls aged 15 and over who have lived in a relationship who have experienced physical or sexual violence in the past 12 months divided by the total of all women and girls aged 15 and over multiplied by 100.
The results of the survey are validated at two levels: technical validation and official validation before publication
The indicator is available at national level
The indicator can be compared to other indicators of the same type at regional and international level
Report of the Demographic and Health Survey 2016-2017

Objective 9. Build a resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization that benefits everyone and encourage innovation

9.3 Increase, especially in developing countries, the access of enterprises, especially small industrial enterprises, to financial services, including loans on affordable terms, and their integration into value chains and markets
9.3.1 Proportion of small businesses in total industry value added

The proportion of "small firms" in total industry value added represents the share of manufacturing value added of small manufacturing firms in total manufacturing value added. A company is the smallest legal unit that constitutes an organizational unit producing goods or services. Industrial enterprises are classified as small versus large or medium-sized for their distinct nature of economic organization, production capacity, scale of investment, and other economic characteristics.
